posts.cooked: We are considering switching from CTRE encoders to TBT encoders due to their lower cost, but we must evaluate the trade-offs. While TBT encoders are cheaper and absolute-magnetic, they may lack the extensive community support and integration tools provided by CTRE. The lack of a swerve code generator with our existing NavX 2 and roboRio setup could hinder progress, requiring more effort to develop custom code. Additionally, wiring differences between the CAN-based and direct connections might complicate our existing systems. Although TBT offers simplicity, its steeper learning curve and potential integration challenges could slow down our development process. Considering our budget and the importance of functionality, maintaining compatibility with our current hardware and ensuring smooth programming may justify the higher initial cost of CTRE encoders.

posts.name: icemannie
posts.cooked: The Thrifty absolute encoders worked well for us. They are an option to consider when using Yet Another Generic Swerve Library (YAGSL).
Were you using a West Coast Products Swerve module? What was programming like? Good to know, though :wink:.

posts.name: icemannie
posts.cooked:
We used SDS and YAGSL libraries. With YAGSL, the Thrifty is one of the options for absolute encoder implementation. The lower-level code remains invisible to the library users.  

With CANCoders, the absolute offset can be stored either in the CANCoder or within your code. Using the Thrifty module, however, stores it solely within your code.  

If you can share a link to your code, further assistance may be available.

link_counts.title: Welcome to Yet Another Swerve Document | YAGSL

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked: There are several online Swerve code templates available where you primarily need to input your specific constants like encoder offsets, inversion settings for steering, driving, and gear ratios. The WPIlib version works well, and I used the AdvantageKit TalonFX example project, though the specific setup isn’t critical. Starting simple is advisable; avoid adding complex features until you establish a reliable foundation (using a template is recommended). Teams often learn from others' mistakes, but since you're using encoders, ensure magnets are securely glued to prevent offset changes as the robot moves—trust me, identifying this issue took time! If you use a NavX, using USB backup power can help prevent disconnections and gyro resets, so consider adding a reset button if you haven't already. Collaboration among team members is essential, especially if you’re working independently; reviewing each other’s code is beneficial even if you aren’t writing it together. Sharing a single computer can be manageable but may cause some inconvenience, so using GitHub could mitigate potential issues. For foundational knowledge, consult the WPIlib documentation to understand how Swerve operates and the available library functions.

Extremely importantly, I’m guessing you used the PWM cable to plug into the roboRio directly as the thrifty bot encoder can’t be integrated onto the CAN controller. It is definitely much cheaper. I’ll run this option through our mentor as well, so we can pick between the CANcoder and the Thriftybot Encoder. I’ll have to confirm if the case is compatible for mounting on our modules but we can probably 3D print a custom one if needed. We’re currently making the choice between the two, and one factor is definitely the price.

Just out of curiosity, how’s the performance of the encoder? Is programming very similar regardless of which one you select? I’m aware that the CANcoder uses the Phoenix 6 library, and you can update it and whatnot in tuner X, but not so sure about the Thrifty Bot one. Thanks for your input!

The WPIlib documentation provides detailed information on how swerve functions and the various methods available for use. GronkBaby mentioned reading through these resources to better understand the system. Sounds good! Just curious, which encoder does your team utilize?

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked: We are using coders. Although for three-fourths of the season, we aligned the wheels before each match, I couldn’t figure out why the encoders weren’t working. Sigh.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked:
The text is:  

You should look into the advantage kit swerve template made by Team 6328. It comes with setup instructions and NAVX code, along with additional tools. You’ll need to adjust the provided NAVX code, but it should work fine. I highly recommend the CANcoders.
